analytic.title: EMOTIONAL LEARNING DYNAMICS IN MDD

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) poses a significant burden for individuals and society. It compromises quality of life, disrupts productivity, and strains social relationships. Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning play an important role in psychopathology, yet the independent and joint contributions of these forms of emotional learning to depressed mood are not well understood. In particular, studies of Pavlovian conditioning and Pavlovian-instrumental transfer (PIT) in MDD are few. Studying PIT in MDD may improve our understanding of how emotional learning influences depressive symptoms that is more reflective of how Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning operate in the real world. In this review, we first provide a narrative summary of past research investigating emotional learning in MDD, including computational modeling approaches. Based on these findings, we then build on an existing theoretical framework characterizing emotional learning and decision making in depression by incorporating the potential influence of Pavlovian conditioned cues on instrumental behaviour in individuals experiencing depressed mood. Specifically, we propose that, in MDD, adaptive instrumental behaviours are interrupted by the exaggerated inhibitory influence of aversive Pavlovian cues and insufficiently invigorated by appetitive Pavlovian cues. We conclude with recommendations for future research investigating emotional learning in MDD.

div.head: Pavlovian and Instrumental Conditioning and Their Mutual Influence in Major Depressive
Disorder: The Mood and Emotional Learning Dynamics (MELD) Framework
div.p: Major Depressive Disorder (MDD) poses significant social and economic costs to individuals, families, and society (Greenberg, Fournier, Sisitsky, Pike, & Kessler, 2015;Kessler, 2012;Lépine & Briley, 2011). It has been estimated that 322 million people are living with MDD worldwide, a prevalence which increased 18% between 2005 and 2015 (World Health Organization, 2017). MDD is the leading cause of disability globally and accounts for 40% of global disease burden attributable to all mental health conditions (Ferrari et al., 2013;Whiteford et al., 2013).

According to the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-5), MDD is predominantly characterized by low mood and/or loss of interest or pleasure (American Psychiatric Association, 2013). Changes in appetite and sleeping patterns, fatigue or loss of energy, psychomotor agitation or retardation, feelings of worthlessness or excessive or inappropriate guilt, concentration difficulties, and thoughts of death or suicide are also common (APA, 2013). A precise characterization of the mechanisms underlying these symptoms may facilitate the development of more targeted and individualized treatments (Insel et al., 2010).

A large body of research has used cognitive science approaches to help characterize, predict, and improve treatment for MDD (Beck & Bredemeier, 2016;Grahek, Everaert, Krebs, & Koster, 2018;Kaiser et al., 2018;LeMoult & Gotlib, 2019;Teasdale, 1999aTeasdale, , 1999bTeasdale, Segal, & Williams, 1995). However, contemporary accounts of the cognitive processes implicated in MDD often omit emotional learning (Grahek et al., 2018), the process by which actions and events or objects in the environment become associated with desirable or undesirable outcomes. A number of recent studies implicate emotional learning in MDD, including Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

computational psychiatry approaches that provide evidence for the contributions of latent aspects of Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning, and their mutual influence (Huys et al., 2016;Huys, Pizzagalli, Bogdan, & Dayan, 2013;Mukherjee, Filipowicz, Vo, Satterthwaite, & Kable, 2020;Nord, Lawson, Huys, Pilling, & Roiser, 2018). The mutual influence of Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning is referred to as Pavlovian-instrumental transfer (PIT), a phenomenon

whereby Pavlovian conditioned stimuli invigorate, suppress, or guide the selection of instrumental behaviours. Emerging evidence suggests that PIT may be altered for individuals with MDD (Huys et al., 2016;Moutoussis et al., 2018;Nord et al., 2018). Bishop and Gagne (2018) recently introduced the altered computations underlying decision making (ACDM) framework characterizing reinforcement learning and decisionmaking in depression and anxiety using a computational perspective (Bishop & Gagne, 2018).

According to their framework, individuals with depression may underestimate the estimated probability and value of future positive events and overestimate the effort required to attain them. The authors note that a bias towards recalling negative rather than positive past experiences could inform pessimistic predictions of the likelihood of future positive events commonly seen in depression (Bjärehed, Sarkohi, & Andersson, 2010;MacLeod & Byrne, 1996;MacLeod & Salaminiou, 2001). Moreover, they propose that exaggerated anticipation of effort cost may contribute to anhedonia symptoms, consistent with previous research (Treadway, Bossaller, Shelton, & Zald, 2012;Treadway, Buckholtz, Schwartzman, Lambert, & Zald, 2009).

A key proposition in their framework is that depression involves blunted anticipation of positive events ('wanting') rather than blunted sensitivity to consummatory reward ('liking'), a proposal that is also supported by previous studies (Bonnelle, Manohar, Behrens, & Husain, 2016;Bonnelle et al., 2015;Chong, Bonnelle, & Husain, 2016). We suggest that, while consistent with Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

a body of findings, this is not the whole picture. Following a review of studies investigating emotional learning in MDD, we build on the ACDM framework to integrate the roles of Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning and PIT in a new theoretical framework. The Mood and
Emotional Learning Dynamics (MELD) framework provides a comprehensive account of how emotional learning and related psychological processes may perpetuate depressed mood in MDD.

To address the limitations outlined above, the current narrative review was carried out to synthesize previous studies investigating Pavlovian conditioning, instrumental conditioning (including computational models of reinforcement learning), and PIT studies in MDD before introducing the MELD framework to integrate past emotional learning findings and inform future research of emotional learning in depression. Our framework proposes that, for acutely Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

div.head: Behavioural Theories of Depression
div.p: A number of behavioural theories of depression emerged following seminal work of Ferster and Skinner (1957) who formally proposed that the likelihood of a behaviour being carried out will be more or less likely depending on whether the behaviour was previously rewarded or punished, respectively (Clark & Beck, 1999). Early behavioural theories of depression emphasized that adaptive behaviours can be reduced significantly in the absence of (1) behaviours resulting in positive experiences that motivate the repetition of those behaviours (i.e., positive reinforcement) and (2) behaviours resulting in successful avoidance of negative experiences (producing a feeling of relief) that also motivate the repetition of those behaviours (i.e., negative reinforcement). When behaviours appear to no longer result in reinforcement, this loss of positive and negative reinforcers can produce an overgeneralized loss of interest and pleasure and a tendency towards helplessness, respectively (Clark & Beck, 1999;Gotlib & Hammen, 1992). Some of the most well-known behavioural theories of depression are those introduced by Ferster (1973), Costello (1972), Lewinsohn (1974), and Seligman (1975), as summarized below. These theories are presented to help provide context for recent research on emotional learning in MDD.

div.head: Ferster (1973): Reduced Frequency of (Reinforced) Behaviour
div.p: In his conceptualization of depression, Ferster (1973) proposed that the defining feature of the condition is the reduced frequency of adaptive behaviours resulting from a lack of positively reinforced behaviours and/or an excess of punished behaviours. For example, insufficient positive reinforcement may lead to reduced engagement in enjoyable activities like meaningful social interactions and excessive punishment may result in reduced engagement in adaptive avoidance or escape behaviours such as actively preventing or resolving interpersonal Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

conflict. Ferster (1973) noted that individuals with depression tend to perform indirect actions that are unlikely to alter or prevent an undesirable situation even though they are motivated by it (e.g., unconstructive complaints, demands that are unrealistic or not feasible), and less often perform direct actions which effectively address (e.g., reduce or terminate) undesirable circumstances. The performance of indirect actions and paucity of direct actions proposed to characterize depression may be explained by excessive punishment preventing direct actions and insufficient reinforcement of direct actions to guide and motivate adaptive behaviour. For example, an individual requesting their partner to go to the movies, attend a party with friends, go for a walk, or do some other activity are examples of direct actions performed to bring about positive experiences. If these requests are repeatedly denied (a lack of positive reinforcement), the individual interested in engaging in these activities may begin to perform indirect actions, such as complaining that their life is boring or that they are always cooped up at home. The goal is the same for these actions, but indirect actions are proposed to be more common for people who are depressed. Unfortunately, indirect actions are often even less likely to result in positive reinforcement, thereby failing to increase the positive reinforcement needed to alleviate depressed mood. Thus, Ferster's (1973) theory suggests the critical role of emotional learning (changes in behaviour resulting from reward and punishment) in depression.

div.head: Lewinsohn (1974): Reduced Effectiveness of Positive Reinforcers
div.p: Consistent with Ferster's (1973) theory, Lewinsohn (1974) proposed that individuals with depression experience a lack of response-contingent reinforcement that leads to the extinction of positively reinforced behaviours. He theorized that depression was determined by (1) the availability of positive reinforcers (e.g., few opportunities to see friends, no access to recreational activities, few contacts with superiors at work who praise work accomplishments)
Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

and aversive experiences (e.g., chronic pain, frequent disdain from a partner), (2) the adequacy/effectiveness of instrumental behaviours to promote positive reinforcement or reduce/eliminate aversive experiences (e.g., poor social skills or problem solving), and/or (3) the number/frequency of positive reinforcers and aversive events (e.g., multiple losses such as a job, partner, home, etc.; Clark & Beck, 1999;Lewinsohn, 1974). Thus, if opportunities to engage in positively reinforcing behaviours are limited and/or there is a preponderance of aversive events, individuals are unlikely to experience the kind of reinforcement that can promote healthy approach and avoidance/escape behaviours and prevent unhealthy ones (Trew, 2011).

Furthermore, reinforcement may not occur if an individual does not have the skills (or believes they do not have the skills) needed to facilitate the behaviour required to bring about reward or avoid punishment. In this case, aversive experiences may be more likely as a consequence of the individual being ineffective at facilitating desirable outcomes and preventing negative ones.

Lastly, if the number and frequency of positive reinforcers are low and/or the number and frequency of aversive events are high, frequency of active behaviour in general is reduced, and the negative consequences that result from inaction are increased. According to Lewinsohn (1974), these patterns of behaviour and environmental conditions are central contributors to the depressed state. Again, this early behavioural theory of depression proposes that rewarding and aversive consequences of behaviour, and the changes in behaviour they cause, can lead to and perpetuate depressed mood, as further explored in recent research of emotional leaning in MDD discussed below.

div.head: Costello (1972): Disrupted Chain of Behaviour
div.p: Costello (1972) sought to explain why the loss of one reinforcer (e.g., a close companion)

would lead to a loss of interest in a variety of reinforcers (e.g., food and sex). He proposed that Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

depression results from a disruption in a chain of behaviour, whereby a break in a chain of reinforced behaviours can reduce all of the behaviours in that chain. For example, for someone who routinely prepares coffee in the morning to enjoy with a partner, the loss of that partner may not only result in the cessation of that ritual, but it may also cause a disruption in the motivation for the individual to get out of bed. This example depicts how the disruption of a component of the chain of behaviours can disrupt other components of the chain explaining certain depressive behaviours. Although disrupted behavioural chaining was central to Costello's (1972) theory, he also emphasized using concepts from Pavlovian conditioning (Pavlov & Gantt, 1928) that an unconditioned stimulus (US, a stimulus that is intrinsically painful or pleasurable), is increased in attractiveness or aversiveness by a conditioned stimulus (CS, an otherwise neutral stimulus that has come to be associated with pain or pleasure) that is presented before it. Thus, Costello's behavioural theory of depression also points to a role of Pavlovian conditioned stimuli in reduced positively reinforced behaviour in depression as we propose below in the MELD framework.

div.head: Seligman (1975): Learned Helplessness
div.p: The learned helplessness model proposed by Seligman (1975) posited that depression results from repeated uncontrollable and inescapable stressors that compromise an individual's sense of control over their life and circumstances (Clark & Beck, 1999). Seligman distinguished two types of learned helplessness, objective and subjective. Objective helplessness refers to situations in which the probability of an aversive outcome is the same regardless of one's response, i.e., there is nothing an individual can do to prevent the aversive event. Subjective helplessness, on the other hand, refers to an individual's belief that the probability of an aversive outcome is the same regardless of the response, whether this is accurate or not. Perhaps the most well-known investigation of learned helplessness was a study by Seligman and Maier (1967) Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

who tested whether already acquired Pavlovian CSs could influence later instrumental conditioning. In their experiment, subjects were first exposed to inescapable shock, and then placed in a shuttle box that would allow them to escape the shock (Seligman & Maier, 1967).

Surprisingly, subjects that experienced inescapable shock prior to the instrumental conditioning paradigm did not learn to escape the shuttle box when given the opportunity to do so, i.e., the conditioned context prevented instrumental escape behaviour (Seligman & Maier, 1967). This is an example of Pavlovian-instrumental transfer (PIT), which we describe in detail in later sections of this review.

div.head: Emotional Learning in MDD
div.p: Until recently, relative to other diagnostic categories, MDD had received less attention in research exploring the clinical implications of altered emotional learning, particularly Pavlovian conditioning and PIT (Nees, Heinrich, & Flor, 2015). However, research to date characterizing emotional learning in MDD suggests that both Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning are implicated in depression (Craske, Meuret, Ritz, Treanor, & Dour, 2016;Dayan & Huys, 2008;Huys et al., 2016;Huys et al., 2013;Huys, Vogelstein, & Dayan, 2009). Furthermore, research exploring the interaction between these two types of emotional learning in the context of MDD has shed light on the complexity of emotional learning processes that may be implicated in depressive symptomology (Huys et al., 2016;Nord et al., 2018). Yet, a comprehensive review of emotional learning in MDD has not been undertaken. The following narrative review aims to address this gap by summarizing previous findings regarding Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning, as well as PIT, in MDD. Notably, there is considerable heterogeneity across individuals diagnosed with MDD in terms of 'subtypes' or patterns of depressive symptoms;
Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.
however, the studies reviewed here represent important groundwork toward a more fine-grained understanding of how emotional learning relates to different dimensions of depressed mood.

div.head: Pavlovian Conditioning
div.p: Pavlovian conditioning is thought to be an evolutionarily adaptive learning process that facilitates the encoding (the conversion of sensory input into a form that can be processed and deposited into memory) and consolidation (the crystallization of recent memories into long-term memory) of information predictive of desirable or undesirable outcomes (Boureau & Dayan, 2011;Rescorla, 1988). It constitutes the pairing of a neutral stimulus (the CS) with a significant event (the US) to facilitate a biological response in the presence of the CS (the conditioned response; CR) that can subsequently be elicited by the CS in the absence of the US. In addition to neutral cues and contexts, vivid visual imagery of a US can also produce a CR (Berridge, 2012;Dadds, Bovbjerg, Redd, & Cutmore, 1997;Holland, 1990). Such learning prepares an organism for future occasions when the US may be presented, as signaled by the presence of the CS. The CR is a direct consequence of the CS that facilitates approach (for desirable outcomes) or avoidance (for undesirable outcomes) (Boureau & Dayan, 2011). That is, it allows us to use cues to predict and approach or avoid good or bad events, respectively.

In human research, laboratory experiments used to study Pavlovian associations typically involve the repeated presentation of a CS, such as a coloured shape, with a significant event, such as the delivery of a monetary or food reward, that elicits a reflexive motivational/emotional response (e.g., increased skin conductance response [SCR]; Dickinson, 2015). Critically, Pavlovian conditioning is a passive learning process, whereby the CS and US are presented together irrespective of a participant's behaviour. If the formation of a Pavlovian association is successful, participants will demonstrate a CR to the CS after it has been paired one or more Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

times with the US, even in the absence of the US. Pavlovian conditioning paradigms typically also include a neutral stimulus that is unpaired with the US (CS-; e.g., an alternative coloured shape) as a control stimulus so that responses to these stimuli can be compared to assess the degree to which a specific Pavlovian association between the CS and US has been formed.

Several measures of Pavlovian conditioning can be derived from experimental Pavlovian conditioning tasks. Two measures commonly derived from Pavlovian conditioning tasks include the acquisition of a CR (learning the association between the CS and the US) and the maintenance or extinction of a CR once the CS no longer predicts the delivery of the US.

Measuring the acquisition (or learning) of a Pavlovian association can be used to assess how susceptible an individual is to forming passive emotional associations between neutral stimuli or contexts and significant events (Dickinson, 2015), whereas measuring the rate of extinction of a CR helps to indicate how resistant an individual is to the diminishing or elimination of associations between a CS and a US once the CS is no longer predictive of the US. In other words, measuring extinction helps to assess an individual's ability to update the emotional value of a neutral stimulus once it no longer signals imminent threat or reward. In the following section, we review previous Pavlovian conditioning studies of currently depressed individuals with MDD.

div.head: Studies Examining Pavlovian Conditioning in MDD
div.p: We identified five previous studies that have examined Pavlovian conditioning in individuals who met diagnostic criteria for a current Major Depressive Episode (MDE; Greer, Trivedi, & Thompson, 2005;Jovanovic et al., 2010;Kuhn et al., 2014;Nissen et al., 2010;Otto et al., 2014). The following is an overview of these studies, including their findings and Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

comparative methodologies. A summary of the key characteristics of these studies are presented 248 in Table 1. 249 Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission. Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

div.head: Characteristics of Previous Studies Examining Pavlovian Conditioning in MDD
div.p: All studies examining Pavlovian conditioning in MDD focused on aversive conditioning (Greer et al., 2005;Jovanovic et al., 2010;Kuhn et al., 2014;Nissen et al., 2010;Otto et al., 2014). Based on the four studies in which participants completed a depressive symptom scale, MDD groups had, on average, either moderate (Greer et al., 2005;Jovanovic et al., 2010;Nissen et al., 2010) or severe (Kuhn et al., 2014) depressive symptoms. There was significant heterogeneity between studies in terms of sample size, conditioning phase examined (i.e., acquisition vs. extinction), the type of US and CS used, the schedule and latency of US delivery, and the CR measured. The number of MDD participants included in these studies ranged from 13 (Otto et al., 2014) to 37 (Kuhn et al., 2014). All studies examined the acquisition of aversive Pavlovian associations and one compared patterns of extinction between MDD and control participants (Kuhn et al., 2014). Of these five previous studies, three employed mild shock as the US (Kuhn et al., 2014;Nissen et al., 2010;Otto et al., 2014) and two used air blasts (Greer et al., 2005;Jovanovic et al., 2010). Four studies used geometric shapes as the CS/CS- (Jovanovic et al., 2010;Kuhn et al., 2014;Nissen et al., 2010;Otto et al., 2014) and one study used auditory tones (Greer et al., 2005). Nissen et al. (2010) and Otto et al. (2014) delivered the US (mild electric shock) immediately after 100% of CS presentations, whereas Kuhn et al. (2014) delivered the US (mild electric shock) immediately after 50% of CS presentations. Jovanovic et al. (2010) delivered a 250 ms air blast to the larynx during the last 250 ms of 100% of CS presentations and Greer et al. (2005) used different delivery schedules across trial blocks, including one block in which air blasts were delivered during the last 150 ms of a 650 ms presentation of the CS; another block in which the CS was presented for 100 ms, followed by a 500 ms inter-stimulus trace interval, and then a 150 ms air blast was delivered; and another in Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

which the CS was presented for 100 ms, followed by a 1000 ms inter-stimulus trace interval, and then the delivery of a 150 ms air blast. In terms of CRs measured, three studies measured fear potentiated startle and two studies measured SCR. The considerable methodological heterogeneity between studies makes the interpretation of results across studies difficult;
however, the following section provides a synthesis of study findings in the context of these methodological differences.

div.head: Findings from Previous Studies Examining Pavlovian Conditioning in MDD
div.p: Regarding overall findings from these five previous studies of Pavlovian conditioning in MDD, two showed that the acquisition of Pavlovian associations between neutral and aversive cues was blunted in MDD (Greer et al., 2005;Otto et al., 2014), one showed that acquisition was enhanced (Nissen et al., 2010), and in two studies, no differences in the acquisition of aversive Pavlovian associations were found in individuals with MDD compared to healthy control participants (Jovanovic et al., 2010;Kuhn et al., 2014). In the single study that examined the extinction of aversive Pavlovian associations conducted by Kuhn et al. (2014), participants with MDD showed enhanced extinction of the association between the CS and CS-relative to control participants whose averaged fear potentiated startle to the CS remained significantly higher than their averaged fear potentiated startle to the CS-during extinction. Thus, based on studies conducted to date, the role of aversive Pavlovian conditioning in MDD is unclear. More reliable findings on the acquisition of aversive Pavlovian associations as well as more studies exploring the extinction of these associations are needed.

When these studies are examined according to phase of Pavlovian conditioning measured, the CS/CS-and US used, the schedule and latency of US delivery, and the CR measured, it remains unclear whether individuals with MDD exhibit altered acquisition and/or Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

extinction of aversive Pavlovian associations. Studies that used mild electric shock as a US and geometric shapes as the CS/CS-showed enhanced (Nissen et al., 2010), normal (Kuhn et al., 2014), and blunted (Otto et al., 2014) acquisition of aversive Pavlovian associations. Studies that employed air blasts as the US (Greer et al., 2005;Jovanovic et al., 2010) also reported inconsistent acquisition results, including normal (Jovanovic et al., 2010) and blunted (Greer et al., 2005) acquisition, although differ ent CSs (geometric shapes versus auditory tones) were employed. Studies in which the US was presented immediately following the CS in 100% of CS trials showed enhanced (Nissen et al., 2010) and blunted (Otto et al., 2014) acquisition. For studies that used a US delivered during the presentation of the CS, acquisition of an aversive Pavlovian association was normal (Jovanovic et al., 2010) or blunted (Greer et al., 2005). Greer et al. (2005) examined aversive Pavlovian conditioning in MDD using tasks that entailed delivery of the US after 500 or 1000 ms inter-trial interval between the presentation of the CR and the presentation of the US. They found that participants with MDD showed significantly blunted acquisition during the task with a 500 ms inter-trial interval and marginally significant blunting during acquisition on the task with a 1000 ms inter-trial interval (Greer et al., 2005).

Examining the findings according to the CR measured also provides a mixed picture. The three studies that employed eye blinks as the CR found that acquisition was either normal (Jovanovic et al., 2010;Kuhn et al., 2014) or blunted (Greer et al., 2005).

In the single study that included a measure of extinction (Kuhn et al., 2014), it was found that during the extinction period individuals with MDD showed complete extinction learning as indicated by undifferentiated startle responses for the CS and the CS-whereas control participants maintained a differential fear potentiated startle between the CS and CS-throughout the extinction phase. This suggests that associations formed between a neutral cue and an Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

aversive event degrades faster and to a greater degree for depressed than nondepressed individuals once the neutral cue no longer predicts the aversive event (Kuhn et al., 2014). Based on this single study, conclusions regarding the nature of extinction in MDD cannot be drawn.

However, it is noteworthy that, compared to the other studies reviewed here, the sample was relatively large (37 for the MDD group and 40 for the control group) and comorbid anxiety symptoms in the MDD group were comparatively low (in the mild range).

div.head: Limitations of Previous Studies Examining Pavlovian Conditioning in MDD
div.p: Studies of Pavlovian conditioning in MDD have employed heterogenous methods with small sample sizes and produced inconsistent findings (Greer et al., 2005;Jovanovic et al., 2010;Kuhn et al., 2014;Nissen et al., 2010;Otto et al., 2014). All of these studies examined the acquisition of aversive Pavlovian associations in MDD, one examined the extinction of these associations, and none examined appetitive Pavlovian conditioning. The absence of appetitive Pavlovian conditioning studies in MDD is surprising given that abnormal processing of reward in MDD is well-established (Bylsma, Morris, & Rottenberg, 2008). Thus, perhaps most notably, future studies are needed to examine appetitive Pavlovian conditioning in MDD. Several instrumental conditioning studies included in this review as well as studies of reward sensitivity indicate that individuals with MDD show altered processing of appetitive stimuli; therefore, it appears reasonable to expect that appetitive Pavlovian conditioning could be an additional marker for MDD (Bylsma et al., 2008;Henriques & Davidson, 2000;Pizzagalli, Iosifescu, Hallett, Ratner, & Fava, 2008;Vrieze et al., 2013). Furthermore, the heterogeneity across studies may be attributable in part to the diverse presentations of mood and related psychological symptoms (e.g., anxiety) across individuals with MDD, and a dimensional approach to Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.
understanding Pavlovian conditioning among individuals with clinically significant depressive symptoms may be warranted.

div.head: Preliminary Summary: Pavlovian Conditioning in MDD
div.p: In sum, of the five previous studies identified that examined Pavlovian conditioning in MDD, all of which focused on aversive (as opposed to appetitive) conditioning, most included small samples, and findings for the acquisition and extinction of aversive Pavlovian associations were inconsistent. More studies are needed to clarify the nature of aversive and, most notably, appetitive Pavlovian conditioning in individuals with MDD. In the next section, we review instrumental conditioning studies in MDD, followed by a review of studies examining PIT in MDD. To bring these findings together, we then propose our framework used to characterize the dynamics of emotional learning in MDD.

div.head: Instrumental Conditioning
div.p: Instrumental conditioning occurs when an organism is more or less likely to engage in a particular behaviour depending on the consequence ( press a lever to receive food or escape a chamber to avoid shock (Fanselow & Poulos, 2005). In human studies, instrumental conditioning is typically operationalized using tasks that require Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

participants to respond a certain way to receive monetary reward or avoid monetary loss. Note that most instrumental conditioning paradigms studies involve decision-making (making a choice between different options). This makes it difficult to differentiate associative learning processes between action and outcome involved in instrumental conditioning from decision-making or choosing between better and worse options. Most paradigms used to assess instrumental conditioning can be described as probabilistic reinforcement learning tasks. These tasks are often designed as discrimination or gambling tasks, as described below.

Probabilistic reinforcement learning discrimination tasks are typically memory or perception tasks that require participants to make correct judgments about stimuli according to some criteria, such as whether a word appeared on a previous word list (in a recognition memory task; Henriques & Davidson, 2000) or which of two stimuli was presented on the screen after a very brief presentation (in a stimulus discrimination task; Pizzagalli et al., 2008). In these tasks, feedback is typically provided regarding correct or incorrect judgments and may be accompanied by varying magnitudes and frequencies of rewards or punishments (Lynn & Barrett, 2014). The basic assumption that informs the interpretation of participants' performance on these tasks is that their responses will be biased towards choices that maximize the size and frequency of rewards and minimize the size and frequency of non-reward or punishments (Frank & Claus, 2006).

Probabilistic reinforcement learning tasks may also be designed as gambling paradigms involving the presentation of a set of cards or options from which participants must make choices based on the different likelihood of receiving a reward and/or avoiding punishment (Schönberg, Daw, Joel, & O'Doherty, 2007). Learning typically occurs through trial-and-error, whereby participants learn to make choices that increase the likelihood of reward and decrease the Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

likelihood of punishment. Probabilistic reinforcement learning tasks may also measure reversal learning by incorporating 'rule reversals' that require participants to detect when advantageous and disadvantageous response probabilities are reversed and to adjust their strategy accordingly (i.e., select the newly advantageous option and avoid the newly disadvantageous option). In the following sections, we review the methodological characteristics, results, and potential limitations of previous studies employing probabilistic reinforcement learning tasks in MDD.

div.head: Studies Examining Instrumental Conditioning in MDD
div.p: We identified ten studies that have examined instrumental conditioning (and decisionmaking) in individuals diagnosed with MDD (Cella, Dymond, & Cooper, 2010;Chase et al., 2010;Henriques & Davidson, 2000;Mukherjee et al., 2020;Murphy, Michael, Robbins, & Sahakian, 2003;Must et al., 2006;Pizzagalli et al., 2008;Steele, Kumar, & Ebmeier, 2007;Taylor Tavares et al., 2008;Vrieze et al., 2013). div.p: No difference.

div.head: Response bias:
div.p: The tendency to indicate that the stimulus paired with the more frequent reward was presented, i.e., the extent to which behaviour is modulated by reinforcement history.

div.head: Discriminability:
div.p: The ability to perceptually distinguish between the two stimuli, i.e., a proxy of task difficulty.

div.head: Probabilistic reversal learning tasks:
div.p: In separate reward and punishment tasks, participants pressed a keyboard button to select one of two fractal stimuli followed by a reward (picture of a quarter indicating $0.25 gain) or punishment (a quarter with a red cross overlaid indicating $0.25 loss) or no reward/punishment (a red dot). One of the two fractal stimuli was rewarded or punished 70% of the time and the

div.head: Proportion of rich choices:
div.p: Choices of the fractal with the higher probability of more positive outcomes (i.e., reward or no punishment).

div.head: Proportion of win-stay and lose-shift choices:
div.p: Repetitions of the same choice when a selection resulted in reward/no punishment and switching fractal choices when a selection resulted in punishment/no reward.

div.head: Proportion of rich choices:
div.p: MDD participants made significantly fewer rich choices in both the reward (d = 0.38) and punishment (d = 0.48) conditions. After reversal, the MDD group appeared to learn the contingencies more slowly in both the reward and punishment conditions.

div.head: Proportion of win-stay and lose-shift choices:
div.p: The proportion of win-stay choices was significantly lower for the MDD participants showed lower sensitivity to learning from positive outcomes.

MDD participants showed poorer reward and punishment reversal learning than CTRL participants. MDD participants made significantly fewer rich choices in both the reward and Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

other 30% of the time. Participants were not informed of the reward/punishment structure but told that one stimulus would be rewarded/punished more often than the other. Unsignalled reversals of this association occurred every 30 trials (out of 90 total).

div.head: Reinforcement:
div.p: Monetary wins and losses. The amount of losses varied between $150 and $350 for deck A (in 5/10 selections); $1250 for deck B (in 1/10 selections); between $25 and $75 for deck C (in 5/10 selections); and $250 for deck D (in 5/10 selections). A similar version of the task was completed subsequently that used decks labeled EFGH.

div.head: Reinforcement:
div.p: Monetary rewards and losses.
Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

div.head: Characteristics of Studies Examining Instrumental Conditioning in MDD
div.p: The number of MDD participants included in the identified studies investigating instrumental conditioning (and decision-making) in MDD ranged from 15 (Steele et al., 2007) to 79 (Vrieze et al., 2013) and their depressive symptom severity varied from mild (Must et al., 2006;Taylor Tavares et al., 2008) to moderate (Henriques & Davidson, 2000;Vrieze et al., 2013) to severe (Cella et al., 2010;Chase et al., 2010;Murphy et al., 2003;Pizzagalli et al., 2008;Steele et al., 2007) on average. In studies that reported anxiety symptoms, participants with MDD had anxiety symptom levels that were either mild (Must et al., 2006) or severe (Chase et al., 2010;Murphy et al., 2003) on average. Mean ages ranged from 33 to 46 years and the percent of female participants ranged from 42-73%.

Most of the reviewed studies employed tasks involving monetary reward and/or loss, including discrimination tasks involving probabilistic reward learning (Henriques & Davidson, 2000;Mukherjee et al., 2020;Pizzagalli et al., 2008;Taylor Tavares et al., 2008;Vrieze et al., 2013) or gambling paradigms (Cella et al., 2010;Must et al., 2006;Steele et al., 2007). In three studies, instrumental conditioning tasks that employed only 'correct' or 'incorrect' feedback (i.e., no monetary gain or loss) were used (Chase et al., 2010;Murphy et al., 2003;Taylor Tavares et al., 2008). The most common measures derived from the probabilistic reinforcement learning tasks employed in these studies were response bias/accuracy (more frequently selecting stimuli that were previously associated with greater reward/less punishment) and reaction time (e.g., changes in reaction time following wins versus losses). Four studies examined reinforcement reversal learning (Cella et al., 2010;Mukherjee et al., 2020;Murphy et al., 2003;Taylor Tavares et al., 2008).

div.head: Findings from Studies Examining Instrumental Conditioning in MDD
div.p: Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

A consensus across most studies was that individuals with MDD did not use reinforcement to optimally inform their response strategies (Cella et al., 2010;Henriques & Davidson, 2000;Mukherjee et al., 2020;Must et al., 2006;Pizzagalli et al., 2008;Steele et al., 2007;Vrieze et al., 2013). MDD participants were also found in two studies to be more likely to change their response strategy following misleading negative feedback, e.g., following 'incorrect' feedback for a stimulus with a more advantageous reinforcement history overall (Murphy et al., 2003;Tavares et al., 2008). Another study reviewed here showed that while no negative bias in responding was observed, there was evidence for reduced trial by trial adjustment in participants with MDD compared to control participants during the training phase of their probabilistic reinforcement learning task (Chase et al., 2010).
In all of the studies that employed discrimination tasks, individuals with MDD were less likely to alter their behaviour in favour of positively reinforced (i.e., monetarily rewarded)

choices (Henriques & Davidson, 2000;Mukherjee et al., 2020;Pizzagalli et al., 2008;Vrieze et al., 2013). Henriques and Davidson (2000) and Mukherjee et al. (2020) also examined how behaviour changed as a function of prior punishment (i.e., money lost). Henriques and Davidson (2000) did not find any difference between MDD and control participants in their tendency to alter decisions about stimuli that were previously associated with punishment (Henriques & Davidson, 2000). Mukherjee et al. (2020) found that the MDD group in their study demonstrated poorer reversal learning in the punishment condition and were less likely to choose more frequently unpunished choices than the control group. In two other studies that examined reversal learning, Cella et al. (2010) observed worse performance among the MDD group following switches between the advantageous and disadvantageous decks on the Iowa gambling task compared to control participants but Tavares et al. (2008) did not find a difference in the Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.
rate of errors per rule reversal between participants in the MDD group versus the control group.

In the studies that employed a gambling task, it was generally reported that individuals with MDD were less likely to make decisions that maximized wins and minimized losses according to prior reinforcement (Cella et al., 2010;Must et al., 2006;Steele et al., 2007).

Dependent variables commonly employed in these studies were response bias (i.e., the extent to which behaviour is modulated by reinforcement history; Henriques & Davidson, 2000;Mukherjee et al., 2020;Pizzagalli et al., 2008;Vrieze et al., 2013), overall tendency to make advantageous selections during a gambling task (Cella et al., 2010;Must et al., 2006;Steele et al., 2007), and patterns of reaction time following task feedback (Chase et al., 2010;Pizzagalli et al., 2008;Steele et al., 2007;Taylor Tavares et al., 2008). Studies that used response bias an as index of instrumental reward conditioning consistently showed that MDD participants were less likely to bias their responses towards more frequently/substantially rewarded stimuli (Henriques & Davidson, 2000;Mukherjee et al., 2020;Pizzagalli et al., 2008;Vrieze et al., 2013). This may suggest an overall greater rigidity in responses among individuals with MDD involving perseveration of responses regardless of choice outcomes. This interpretation is supported by the findings of Chase et al. (2010), which showed less trial-by-trial adjustment in responses among individuals with MDD compared to control participants. Studies that examined the tendency to make advantageous decisions over the course of a task according to both reward and punishment all showed that individuals with MDD performed worse than control participants (Cella et al., 2010;Must et al., 2006). Steele et al. (2007) showed that individuals with MDD were less likely to alter their reaction time as a function of task feedback, although Chase et al. (2010) found that depressed and nondepressed participants had similar patterns of reaction time adjustment after Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission. correct vs. incorrect feedback (i.e., slower responses after 'incorrect' compared to 'correct' feedback), although depressed participants had slower reaction times overall.

Notably, the gambling tasks employed in instrumental conditioning studies of MDD involved conscious decision-making processes (Maia & McClelland, 2004), whereas the discrimination tasks are more likely to assess the acquisition of implicit associations between behaviours and reinforcing outcomes (Berry, Shanks, & Henson, 2008). Thus, the findings from studies that employed gambling paradigms may assess the influence of reinforcement on consciously informed choices, whereas the findings from studies that employ signal detection approaches may provide more insight about choices informed by less explicit information.

div.head: Limitations of Previous Studies Examining Instrumental Conditioning in MDD
div.p: Studies that examined instrumental conditioning in MDD using rewards and punishments employed secondary, rather than primary, reinforcers (i.e., money). In other words, the rewards and punishments employed in these studies were stimuli previously associated with one or more primary reinforcers. Therefore, future studies that employ primary (i.e., food or shock) rewards and punishments are needed to understand more comprehensively how individuals with MDD alter their behaviour in response to rewarding and punishing experiences. Furthermore, a limitation of the gambling tasks employed in these studies is that it is difficult to distinguish between participants' responses to rewards versus punishments. Thus, the finding across these studies that participants were less likely to make advantageous choices (Cella et al., 2010;Must et al., 2006;Steele et al., 2007) could be due to a reduced ability to learn from reward, punishment, or both. Separate gambling paradigms or phases within paradigms that distinguish behavioural responses to rewards and punishments could help address this issue.

div.head: Preliminary Summary: Instrumental Conditioning in MDD
div.p: Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

In sum, instrumental conditioning studies have demonstrated three main patterns of results. First, individuals with MDD may be less effective at using reinforcement history (both reward and punishment) to maximize advantageous choices and minimizes disadvantageous ones than nondepressed individuals on gambling tasks (Cella et al., 2010;Mukherjee et al., 2020;Murphy et al., 2003;Must et al., 2006;Taylor Tavares et al., 2008), including after a reversal in probabilistic contingencies (Cella et al., 2010;Mukherjee et al., 2020), and misleading negative feedback (Murphy et al., 2003;Taylor Tavares et al., 2008). The findings presented here also suggest that individuals with MDD do not develop response biases toward more frequently reinforced stimuli when required to discriminate based on visual perception (Pizzagalli et al., 2008;Vrieze et al., 2013) and verbal memory (Henriques & Davidson, 2000) in discrimination tasks. There is some evidence that participants with MDD were less likely to alter their response strategy or style following positive and negative consequences (e.g., less trial-by-trial response adjustment, slowed reaction time after negative feedback or increased reaction time following positive feedback) on decision-making tasks than nondepressed controls (Chase et al., 2010;Steele et al., 2007).

In light of recent developments in computational approaches to studying instrumental conditioning, including those used in studies of MDD, we provide below an overview of studies employing computational modeling of instrumental conditioning in MDD aimed at improving measurement and characterization of latent aspects of cognition that may underlie and/or contribute to depressive symptoms. A critical advantage of using computational modeling is that the parameters included in these models represent latent constructs implicated in MDD, such as reward sensitivity and learning rate, that can be computed and compared across tasks and studies, making it easier to compare findings (Bishop & Gagne, 2018;Kriegeskorte & Douglas, 2018).
Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

We follow this section with a summary and synthesis of research incorporating both Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning in investigations of PIT that helped to inform the development of the MELD framework.

div.head: Contributions of Computational Models to Instrumental Conditioning Research in MDD
div.p: The use of computational psychiatry approaches to characterize reinforcement learning in depression has increased in recent years (Chase et al., 2010;Dombrovski, Szanto, Clark, Reynolds, & Siegle, 2013;Huys et al., 2013;Mukherjee et al., 2020). Computational models allow for the operationalization of formal parameters indicating aspects of cognition that are not apparent from behavioural responses but are latently operating and contributing to behaviour (Kriegeskorte & Douglas, 2018). They also allow for the testing of competing models of the degree to which they predict behaviour in different populations. Common models of reinforcement learning include the traditional Rescorla-Wagner (RW) model (Dombrovski et al., 2010), temporal difference (TD) models, and Q-learning models (Huys et al., 2013;Mukherjee et al., 2020). Examples of parameters representing latent aspects of cognition in these models include positive and negative prediction error (PE), reward and punishment learning rate and sensitivity, exploitation/exploration, memory, and delayed discounting of reward/punishment (Chase et al., 2010;Dombrovski et al., 2010;Huys et al., 2013;Mukherjee et al., 2020).

Most computational models incorporate a PE parameter representing the degree to which unexpected rewards generate a PE. Over time the cue-reward contingency is learned, after which the cue will elicit an expected value signal, or an expectation of the consequence (reward or punishment) of a given choice based on previous reinforcement. In the RW model, learning ceases after knowledge of the cue-reward contingency is acquired and, consequently, there is no PE after the contingency is learned. In TD models, however, a PE is produced whenever the cue Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

appears, including after the cue-reward contingency has been learned. Here, the magnitude of the PE reflects the expected magnitude of the predicted reward. In Q-learning models, a reward sensitivity or exploration/exploitation parameter is included to account for individual differences in these aspects of cognition distinct from learning rate, suggesting that reward sensitivity and exploration/exploitation make unique contributions to predicting behaviour that are not necessarily accounted for by learning rate. Findings from studies that employed computational models to investigate instrumental conditioning in MDD are presented below.

Chase et al. (2010) used a Q-learning model to examine reward and punishment learning rate during training and test phases of a probabilistic reinforcement learning task performed by individuals with MDD and nondepressed control participants. In the training phase of the task, participants selected one letter from one of three stimulus pairs (AB, CD, EF), each with a varying probability of being correct, and feedback ('correct' or 'incorrect') was provided (no reward or punishment) from which participants were expected to learn and select which letter was 'correct' most often. This was followed by a test phase in which participants completed the same task without feedback. Parameters in their model included positive and negative learning rate parameters (indicating efficiency of using PEs to update the expected value of a certain choice during future trials) and an exploration-exploitation parameter (indicating a participant's tendency to choose the option with the highest expected payoff or choose an option for which the payoff is not yet known). The learning rate parameters are included in the Q-learning model where the Q-value, representing the associative strength of the just-selected stimulus to a particular outcome, is updated as a function of whether the outcome was positive or negative, the learning rate, and the PE (outcomeexpected outcome for that trial). The exploitation/exploration parameter is used in the computation of the probability of selecting Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

either the stimulus known to result in a positive outcome or the stimulus for which the outcome is unknown. The authors found that MDD participants showed a reduced learning rate for both correct and incorrect feedback (i.e., for positive and negative PEs) in the reinforcement learning training phase but not in the test phase of their experiment. Furthermore, they found that poorer reward and punishment learning rate in the training phase was associated with greater anhedonia in all study participants (including MDD and control participants).

A study by Dombrovski et al. (2010) that used a modified RW model to examine parameters influencing reinforcement learning, using a probabilistic reversal learning task in suicide attempters, suicide ideators, nonsuicidal depressed elderly, and nondepressed comparison subjects. Consistent with the traditional RW model, they calculated the optimal expected values of choosing stimulus 1 or stimulus 2 based on a prior (the previously expected outcome) and a PE (the difference between the experienced outcome and the prior). Their model also included learning rate parameters for rewards and punishments and a memory parameter. Learning rate parameters captured the impacts of positive (reward) and negative (punishment) PE on the previous trial (t -1) on the participant's subsequent choice (t), whereas the memory parameter reflected the effect of reward and punishment history on all previous trials on choice (low memory results in rapid switches of choice in response to reward/punishment on the last trial).
The authors found that participants with MDD tended to exhibit a (marginally) lower punishment learning rate than control participants but reward learning rate did not differ between groups.
These findings suggest that trial choices that resulted in negative (but not positive) PEs had a blunted influence on stimulus choice in the subsequent trial in MDD participants.

In a behavioural meta-analytic study by Huys et al. (2013), a Q-learning model was used to examine probabilistic reward learning task performance in participants with MDD compared Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.
to nondepressed control participants. During the task, participants were required to discriminate between two visual stimuli and select the stimulus most likely to result in a rewarding outcome.

The parameters of interest included (1) reward sensitivity and (2) a learning rate parameter that incorporated reward and punishment. This study revealed that the reward sensitivity parameter predicted altered behaviour in MDD more than learning rate and the authors therefore concluded that MDD is associated with blunted appetitive learning resulting from a reduced primary sensitivity to rewards as opposed to reduced reward learning rates.

Mukherjee et al. (2020) employed a Q-learning computational model to examine performance on two probabilistic reversal learning tasks in MDD and nondepressed control participants, including one task incorporating only reward/no reward feedback and another task incorporating only punishment/no punishment feedback. Parameters of interest in their models for both tasks were value sensitivity and learning rates. Their results showed that MDD participants had slower reward and punishment learning rates, lower punishment value sensitivity, and marginally lower reward value sensitivity than control participants. Notably, Mukherjee et al. (2020) found that the parameters used in their model better classified participants with MDD than simpler metrics of performance, including proportion of rich fractal choices, proportion of win-stay responses, and action perseveration.

In sum, these four previous studies used computational models to examine reward and/or punishment learning and sensitivity, as well as exploitation-exploration, in MDD with mixed results. Nonetheless, there was some consensus that individuals with MDD had lower reward and punishment sensitivity (Huys et al., 2013;Mukherjee et al., 2020) and learning rates (Chase et al., 2010;Dombrovski et al., 2010;Mukherjee et al., 2020) than nondepressed control participants. Importantly, there was evidence that emotional learning parameters included in Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

computational models were better at discriminating MDD from nondepressed control participants than simpler metrics of performance (Mukherjee et al., 2020). Thus, computational modeling of latent aspects of emotional learning in MDD may be superior to non-computational behavioural indices for identifying MDD.

div.head: Pavlovian-Instrumental Transfer
div.p: PIT refers to a process by which Pavlovian CSs can invigorate or suppress instrumental behaviour. Appetitive and aversive PIT effects are differentiated such that appetitive PIT occurs when an appetitive CS invigorates instrumental approach or inhibits instrumental withdrawal (Cartoni, Balleine, & Baldassarre, 2016) and aversive PIT takes place when an aversive CS inhibits instrumental approach or invigorates instrumental withdrawal (Huys et al., 2011).
Appetitive and aversive PIT can also be described as the influences of appetitive and aversive expectations on behaviour, respectively (Geurts, Huys, Den Ouden, & Cools, 2013). Pavlovian

CSs have been found to influence instrumental behaviour by (1) increasing the likelihood that an action (approach or withdrawal) associated with the Pavlovian US will be carried out and 2inducing motivational states consistent with those elicited by Pavlovian US. Specific and general PIT are two putative subtypes of PIT. Specific PIT refers to situations in which both the Pavlovian and instrumental associations are formed with the exact same outcome (e.g., delivery of a shock) and the presence of the CS is found to alter (invigorate or suppress) instrumental behaviour associated with that specific outcome. For example, the presence of a CS previously paired with shock would be expected to invigorate instrumental avoidance behaviour intended to escape a shock. General PIT refers to situations in which the general motivational properties of a CS invigorates or suppresses instrumental behaviour even though the CS is different from the instrumental reinforcer/punishment, for example if the presence of a CS previously paired with Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.
shock were to suppress an instrumental behaviour previously associated with the delivery of a reward.

Most laboratory experiments designed to examine PIT involve separate Pavlovian and instrumental training stages (either training stage may occur first), followed by the instrumental task in the presence of the CS during extinction. During performance on a PIT task, the CS may alter the number, frequency, or choice of an action (Holmes, Marchand, & Coutureau, 2010). A graphical depiction of a human laboratory PIT task is presented in Figure 1.

Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission. Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

Other studies that have examined PIT using prepotent responding as a form of preexisting Pavlovian bias. It has been proposed that producing a response when seeking a reward (versus when avoiding punishment) and omitting a response when avoiding punishment (versus seeking reward) are built-in response tendencies that accompany Pavlovian learning (Guitart-Masip et al., 2012). Thus, in these paradigms, it is assumed that Pavlovian expectations of reward reflexively invigorate active go responses and expectations of punishment inhibit active go responses (Crockett, Clark, & Robbins, 2009;Dayan, Niv, Seymour, & Daw, 2006;Guitart-Masip et al., 2011).

div.head: A Hypothetical 'Real Life' Example of PIT in MDD
div.p: Instrumental Reward Conditioning. Martin, who was recently diagnosed with MDD, often texts friends and family for emotional support. They tend to be kind and supportive, which reinforces his tendency to reach out.

Aversive Pavlovian Conditioning. Since Martin became depressed, his productivity at work has declined, and his boss occasionally sends him emails criticizing his performance. As a result, Martin tends to experience a sense of dread when he hears or sees email notifications on his smartphone or computer.

Enhanced Aversive PIT. One evening, Martin was in bed feeling particularly stressed about work and decided to text his friend as a distraction. As he reached for the phone, an unexpected email notification popped up, and a feeling of dread overcame him. This feeling hampered his motivation to text his friend, and he retreated to his bed instead.

The above example illustrates how PIT may operate to reduce positive reinforcement in individuals with MDD, a critical factor in the onset and maintenance of depressed mood (Costello, 1972;Ferster, 1973;Lewinsohn, 1974;Seligman, 1975). Although Martin has Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

successfully acquired the instrumental behaviour of contacting friends and family for support, the aversive CR associated with email notifications interfered with his ability to perform this action and successfully obtain social support.

div.head: Studies Examining PIT in MDD
div.p: Human PIT is a relatively new area of research (Talmi, Seymour, Dayan, & Dolan, 2008), and paradigms examining PIT in humans has only recently been applied to individuals with MDD (Huys et al., 2016;Moutoussis et al., 2018;Nord et al., 2018). Investigations of PIT in MDD have included two studies that employed instrumental and Pavlovian training and PIT testing during a major depressive episode (Huys et al., 2016;Nord et al., 2018) as well as one study that investigated prepotent Pavlovian biases to respond for reward and omit a response to avoid no-reward during an instrumental conditioning task (Moutoussis et al., 2018). The characteristics and main findings of these studies are presented in Table 3.

The approach condition involved click-tocollect ("go") or withhold response to discard ("no-go"). The withdrawal condition involved click-todiscard ("go") or withhold response to keep ("no-go"). Each mushroom colour was associated with a different probability of being rewarded or punished based on

div.p: PIT was actionspecific in controls but not patients; there was a trend-wise difference between MDD and CTRL groups.
In the depressed state the guidance of choices afforded by Pavlovian stimuli was reduced and lacked specificity.
