div.head: Characteristics of Studies Examining PIT in MDD
div.p: Three previous studies have examined PIT in individuals diagnosed with MDD. MDD participants in all of these studies were found to have moderate depressive symptoms, were 28 (Huys et al., 2016;Nord et al., 2018) and 34 (Moutoussis et al., 2018) years old on average, and were comprised of 39% (Nord et al., 2018), 56% (Moutoussis et al., 2018), and 68% (Huys et al., 2016) female participants. Two studies employed the same paradigm in which participants first underwent an instrumental training phase, then a Pavlovian training phase, and finally a PIT phase (Huys et al., 2016;Nord et al., 2018). For the instrumental training phase in these studies, participants either learned to (1) 'click-to-collect' certain coloured mushrooms and 'withhold response to discard' others in order to maximize rewards and minimize losses; or (2) 'click-todiscard' certain coloured mushrooms and 'withhold response to keep' others in order to maximize rewards and minimize losses. These two conditions were used to measure approach and withdrawal PIT, respectively. If successful, participants would learn which mushroom colours were associated with reward versus punishment when collected/discarded, developing approach and withdrawal biases according to each mushroom's reinforcement history. In the study by Moutoussis et al. (2018), a prepotent Pavlovian bias during an instrumental conditioning task was examined, whereby participants learned to respond to fractal images with 'Go-to-Win', 'Go-to-Avoid-Loss', 'NoGo-to-Win', and 'NoGo-to-Avoid-Loss' conditions that would produce a monetary reward (win) or a monetary loss (no win). The Pavlovian influence in this study was the tendency to 'Go-to-Win' and 'NoGo-to-Avoid-Loss'.

div.head: Findings from Studies Examining PIT in MDD
div.p: To investigate whether PIT may be altered in MDD, Huys et al. (2016) examined differences in action-specificity between individuals diagnosed with MDD and nondepressed Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

participants. Action-specificity in the context of PIT refers to the tendency for appetitive CSs to selectively invigorate active approach behaviours and aversive CSs to selectively invigorate active withdrawal behaviours. In the instrumental approach training phase of Huys and colleagues' (2016) PIT paradigm, participants learned to collect or not collect mushrooms according to the actions' associated consequences. Specifically, participants learned to (1) click on mushrooms for which (a) clicking frequently resulted in reward and infrequently resulted in punishment and (b) not clicking frequently resulted in punishment/infrequently resulted in reward ('go' to obtain reward/avoid punishment) or (2) refrain from clicking on mushrooms for which (a) not clicking was frequently rewarded/infrequently punished and (b) clicking was frequently punished/infrequently rewarded ('no-go' to obtain reward/avoid punishment). In the instrumental withdrawal training phase of their paradigm, participants learned to discard or keep mushrooms depending on reinforcement. This involved clicking on an empty box opposite mushrooms to discard ('go' to obtain reward/avoid punishment) and withhold clicking on the empty box to keep the mushroom ('no-go' to obtain reward/avoid punishment). Responses (or lack thereof) resulted in either reward or punishment during every trial with the same reinforcement schedule as the approach training.
The authors observed that in nondepressed individuals, PIT effects were action-specific.

In the approach PIT task ('go' to collect or 'no-go' to not collect mushrooms), control participants were overall (i.e., averaged across all instrumental stimuli) more likely to produce a 'go to collect' response when an appetitive CS was presented and less likely to produce a 'go to collect' response when an aversive CS was presented (suggesting that appetitive CSs invigorated active approach and aversive CSs suppressed active approach responses), whereas instrumental training that involved withdrawal ('go to discard' mushrooms or 'no-go to keep'), participants Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

were overall more likely to produce an active withdrawal response when an aversive CS was presented and less likely to produce an active withdrawal response when an appetitive CS was presented. Notably, the authors found that greater action-specificity in the control group (i.e., an appetitive CS boosts active approach and inhibits active withdrawal; an aversive CS boosts active withdrawal and inhibits active approach) was driven more by PIT effects during approach than withdrawal (Huys et al., 2016). One explanation for this distinction could be that 'go' (i.e., active) responses are more likely in the face of potential rewards (signaled by appetitive CSs) and 'no-go' responses are more likely in the face of potential punishments (signaled by aversive CSs). This may have resulted in stronger PIT effects when active responses were associated with appetitive CSs and passive responses were associated with aversive CSs and weaker PIT effects when an active response was required in the presence of an aversive CS and passive response in the presence of an appetitive CS, contrary to pre-potent Pavlovian biases to produce a motor response in the presence of an appetitive stimulus and withhold a motor response in the presence of an aversive stimulus (Crockett et al., 2009;Dayan et al., 2006;Guitart-Masip et al., 2011;Guitart-Masip et al., 2012).

Unlike the pattern of results observed in control participants, PIT was not action specific in participants with MDD (Huys et al., 2016). For depressed participants, the valence of the CS did not appear to affect instrumental approach or withdrawal. The presentation of an appetitive or aversive CS was not associated with an increased likelihood of "clicking to obtain" or "clicking to discard", respectively. The finding that the difference in PIT effects between MDD and control participants was most clearly observed for instrumental approach behaviours is consistent with behavioural theories of depression which propose that MDD is driven largely by Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.
a lack of positively reinforced behaviours (i.e., fewer actions that bring about pleasurable consequences; Dimidjian, Barrera Jr, Martell, Munoz, & Lewinsohn, 2011).

In their study of PIT in participants with MDD compared to nondepressed participants, Moutoussis et al. (2018) did not observe differences in Pavlovian influences on instrumental behaviour, although their study assessed pre-potent Pavlovian biases as opposed to Pavlovian associations formed during training included in a PIT paradigm. Using a computational modeling approach, they examined whether individuals with MDD differed from control participants in terms of several parameters, with a Pavlovian bias parameter used to examine PIT (representing the tendency to produce a button press for rewards and withdraw a button press for punishments). The authors found that the Pavlovian bias to produce a button press for rewards and withdraw a button press for punishments did not differ between MDD and control participants (Moutoussis et al., 2018). Thus, MDD participants performed similarly to controls in their tendency to 'go' to obtain rewards and 'no-go' to avoid punishment.

An important consideration when comparing the disparate results of the studies by Huys et al. (2016) and Moutoussis et al. (2018) is that the latter study examined the influence of a prepotent Pavlovian bias in motor responding on instrumental behaviour in MDD compared to nondepressed control participants. In contrast, Huys et al. (2016) examined the influence of a newly formed Pavlovian association between a visual stimulus and a rewarding or punishing outcome on instrumental behaviour. Furthermore, the instrumental actions in the two studies differ in that the study by Moutoussis et al. (2018) required a simpler instrumental action: 'go' or 'no-go' following the presentation of a fractal image to obtain a reward or avoid a punishment.

The study by Huys et al. (2016), however, required more complex instrumental actions involving moving the cursor towards a stimulus and clicking on it (versus no action) in an approach phase Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

or moving a cursor away from a stimulus and clicking on an empty box opposite the stimulus (versus no action) in a withdrawal phase. Examining the pattern of responding within either of these phases may have produced similar results, whereby a 'go' response is more likely for previously rewarded stimulus (whether 'clicking on' to collect or 'clicking away' to discard) and a 'no-go' response is more likely for a previously punished stimulus (whether 'not clicking on'
to not collect or 'not clicking away' to keep). However, these analyses were not completed.

Thus, it may be that while individuals with MDD show a similar Pavlovian bias to nondepressed individuals in their motor responding during instrumental tasks ('go' to win and 'no-go' to avoid punishment), they do not show the same patterns of Pavlovian bias for newly formed stimulusoutcome associations and/or more complex instrumental actions.

In a recent study of aversive PIT by Nord et al. (2018), it was found that instrumental behaviours in individuals with MDD, whether involving approach or withdrawal, were significantly more influenced by aversive Pavlovian cues than was the case for nondepressed participants. Notably, groups performed comparably on the Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning tasks during training. However, during the aversive PIT task, MDD patients performed significantly fewer active approach responses ('click' to obtain) and significantly more active withdrawal responses ('click' to discard) when Pavlovian CSs predicted both small and large losses. Thus, aversive Pavlovian cues impaired performance in the approach condition and enhanced performance in the withdrawal condition. Again, Moutoussis et al. (2018) did not obtain results that were consistent with the study by Nord et al. (2018); they did not find any influence of the 'NoGo-to-Avoid-Loss' Pavlovian bias on instrumental behaviour in their study.

The results of Nord et al.'s (2018) study were not consistent with those of Huys et al. (2016), in that participants in with MDD did show action-specificity in their responses when Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

aversive Pavlovian CSs were presented. Nord et al. (2018) reported that the most likely explanation for these somewhat conflicting results is that, unlike Huys et al. (2016), they did not include participants who were taking psychotropic medication. Another difference between these studies was that 62% of participants in Nord et al. (2018) study had a comorbid anxiety disorder,
whereas individuals with anxiety disorders were excluded from Huys et al. (2016) study.

However, Nord et al. (2018) examined whether anxiety disorder comorbidity impacted their results and did not observe any effect. Thus, it is possible that unmedicated individuals with MDD exhibit exaggerated aversive Pavlovian influence over instrumental behaviour whereas psychotropic medication blunts this effect resulting in action-nonspecific effects of Pavlovian cues on instrumental behaviour in individuals with the disorder.

div.head: Preliminary Summary: PIT in MDD
div.p: In sum, there is mixed evidence to date indicating that individuals with MDD may show diminished action-specific influence of Pavlovian cues over instrumental behaviour (Huys et al., 2016) or exaggerated influence of aversive Pavlovian cues over instrumental behaviour (Nord et al., 2018) than nondepressed controls. Yet there was no evidence for a pre-potent Pavlovian response bias for individuals with MDD relative to healthy controls (Moutoussis et al., 2018).

The results of these studies may suggest that paradigms employing measures of prepotent Pavlovian bias do not distinguish depressed from nondepressed individuals, whereas paradigms which include Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning training phases preceding the testing of PIT may better distinguish these groups.

div.head: Recommendations for Future Research Investigating PIT in MDD
div.p: Evidently, studies examining PIT in MDD are few, and more studies are needed to establish how Pavlovian CSs influence instrumental behaviour in depression. Thus far, a single Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.
PIT paradigm has demonstrated altered Pavlovian control over instrumental behaviour in MDD.

In this paradigm, monetary wins and losses were used to induce Pavlovian and instrumental conditioned associations (Huys et al., 2016;Nord et al., 2018 (Cartoni, Puglisi-Allegra, & Baldassarre, 2013). Furthermore, as noted above, the results of the two studies that employed the same paradigm were inconsistent (Huys et al., 2016;Nord et al., 2018), highlighting that more replication studies are needed to more reliably establish how performance on this particular PIT tasks differs between individuals with MDD and nondepressed control participants. It may also be worthwhile to examining the effect of psychotropic medication on PIT in MDD, given that a possible explanation for the disparate results obtained by Huys et al. (2016) and Nord et al. (2018) is that treatment with psychotropic medication was an exclusion criterion only in the latter study.

The results of the study by Moutoussis et al. (2018) did not support a difference in prepotent Pavlovian influence on instrumental behaviour between participants with MDD and the control group. This may suggest that individuals with MDD show intact pre-potent Pavlovian Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

bias (e.g., a pre-potent Pavlovian bias to have an approach motor response -'go'to obtain rewards and a withdrawal-congruent motor response -'no-go'to avoid punishment) but demonstrate either action-nonspecific (Huys et al., 2016) or aversively-biased (Nord et al., 2018) influence of Pavlovian cues that have been newly associated with a US. However, additional studies examining pre-potent Pavlovian influences on instrumental behaviour in MDD are clearly needed. Furthermore, it will be important to examine whether appetitive and aversive PIT differ according to various dimensions of the phenomenology of MDD. For example, anhedonia may selectively reduce the degree to which appetitive Pavlovian CSs elicit an approach response whereas cognitive aspects of MDD (e.g., helplessness) may be associated with enhanced aversive PIT in MDD (Husain & Roiser, 2018;Seligman & Maier, 1967).

Overall, there exists a significant gap in our understanding of how Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning interact to affect individuals with MDD. Although there is much work to be done, the first studies of PIT in MDD demonstrate that examining Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning and their mutual influence in a single paradigm shows promise for better understanding this complex disorder. To help reconcile the existing research of emotional learning in MDD, we propose the following framework to capture the nuanced interactions of Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning and how they may operate in MDD.

div.head: The Mood and Emotional Learning Dynamics (MELD) Framework
div.p: In this section, we present a theoretical framework of PIT in MDD. Our framework builds on findings from previous studies examining Pavlovian conditioning, instrumental conditioning, and PIT in MDD. The MELD framework is intended to fill a gap in the conceptualization of how Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning operate together to influence the reduced frequency of reinforcement in MDD (or subtypes of MDD), which is posited to Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

contribute its onset and maintenance (Dimidjian et al., 2011;Ferster, 1973;Jacobson, Martell, & Dimidjian, 2001;Lewinsohn, 1974). Largely consistent with research to date investigating PIT in MDD, we propose that individuals with MDD show exaggerated influence of aversive Pavlovian cues on instrumental behaviour generally (Nord et al., 2018) and blunted influence of appetitive Pavlovian cues on active approach behaviours in particular (Huys et al., 2016). Our framework focuses on the influence of Pavlovian associations formed during a Major Depressive Episode on instrumental behaviours; therefore, it does not portray the potential influence of pre-potent Pavlovian biases on instrumental behaviour as investigated by Moutoussis et al. (2018).

The MELD framework proposes a simplified pathway through which instrumental behaviour, triggered by the opportunity to obtain a pleasant outcome or avoid/escape a negative one, is determined under the influence of Pavlovian CSs. The framework also incorporates biases in attention and memory, which have been shown to play an important role in the psychopathology of MDD (Beck & Bredemeier, 2016;Kaiser et al., 2018;LeMoult & Gotlib, 2019). In the following sections, we elaborate on the various components of the framework and how they may be altered in MDD. A schematic of the MELD framework is presented in Figure 2.

div.head: Environmental and Motivational Factors Determine Instrumental Outcome Value
div.p: Environmental contributions to the dynamics of emotional learning in MDD incorporated in the MELD framework include an opportunity for reinforcement and the surrounding cues and context, which may serve as Pavlovian CSs. Due to negative attentional biases, which refers to the tendency to notice unpleasant aspects of the environment and attend to them longer relative to pleasant aspects of the environment (Gotlib, Krasnoperova, Yue, & Joormann, 2004;Koster, De Raedt, Goeleven, Franck, & Crombez, 2005), individuals with MDD are proposed to detect fewer opportunities for reward and more opportunities for punishment, as well as fewer environmental cues and contexts associated with desirable outcomes and more associated with aversive outcomes (appetitive and aversive Pavlovian CSs, respectively; Anderson, 2016;Leong, Radulescu, Daniel, DeWoskin, & Niv, 2017). An example of this may be an individual with MDD who is considering where to order in a food court (opportunity for reinforcement) and

focuses their attention on the tense facial expressions of patrons waiting in long line ups (aversive CS predicting unpleasant experience of waiting in the line) rather than the positive facial expressions of people enjoying the food they ordered (appetitive CS predicting delicious food).

As depicted in the MELD framework, once opportunities to obtain rewards or avoid/escape punishments are detected, there is recall of 'liking' or 'disliking' the outcome, which manifests as explicitly remembered or imagined declarative targets (Berridge & Aldridge, 2008). This reaction then produces varying degrees of cognitive desire or aversion, i.e., conscious desire for or aversion to an explicitly expected outcome such as delicious food or waiting in a long lineup, respectively (Berridge & Aldridge, 2008). Recall of how much an Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

individual 'liked' or 'disliked' an outcome in the past and its influence on cognitive desire or aversion may also be referred to as the 'remembered utility' of the outcome, i.e., an individual's retrospective evaluation of past experiences (Berridge, Robinson, & Aldridge, 2009;Kahneman, Wakker, & Sarin, 1997;Schacter et al., 2012;Wassum, Ostlund, Balleine, & Maidment, 2011).

In MDD, we hypothesize that cognitive desire is attenuated, whereas cognitive aversion is potentiated, partly due to negative memory biases for the pleasantness or unpleasantness of experiences (Dillon & Pizzagalli, 2018;Gershman & Daw, 2017). The nature of negative memory biases in MDD and depressed mood include better memory for negative experiences and worse memory for positive experiences (Urban, Charles, Levine, & Almeida, 2018).

Elaborating on the food court example, an individual with MDD who decided to wait in line for delicious food would be expected to recall the unpleasant experience of waiting in line better than the pleasant experience of enjoying the meal.

In addition to the detection of opportunities for reinforcement, surrounding Pavlovian CSs elicit conditioned responses (CRs) and contribute to the motivational salience of the instrumental outcome (Berridge et al., 2009). The motivational salience of an instrumental outcome refers to the degree to which a stimulus elicits approach (incentive salience) or avoidance (aversive salience). In the MELD framework, motivational salience is also determined by an individual's physiological state (e.g., hunger, stress levels; Wassum et al., 2011). The influence of physiological state on motivational salience has been demonstrated in studies of reward devaluation, including findings that satiating hunger reduces the incentive salience of food cues (Balleine & Dickinson, 1998). Referring back to the food court example, the motivational salience of food (the instrumental outcome) would be influenced by the facial expressions of the food vendor's patrons when they are enjoying the food (appetitive CS) and the Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

individual's level of hunger. In MDD, another relevant physiological state that would alter motivational salience is heightened stress, which can increase the motivational salience of aversive outcomes (van Marle, Hermans, Qin, & Fernández, 2009).

In the MELD framework, instrumental outcome value is based on both the motivational salience of an outcome (the degree to which the outcome elicits an implicit approach or avoidance response) and an individual's cognitive desire or aversion towards the outcome (the degree to which the outcome is explicitly represented as desirable or undesirable; Berridge et al., 2009;Olney, Warlow, Naffziger, & Berridge, 2018). The lower the instrumental outcome value, the lower the likelihood that the instrumental action will be carried out (i.e., inaction may result). If the instrumental outcome value is high, the process of action selection will follow.

div.head: Action selection
div.p: Action selection is the process through which an instrumental action (or inaction) is chosen to maximize the probability of a desired outcome (Balleine & Ostlund, 2007). Action selection is proposed to result from the recall of past actions and their outcomes (i.e., reinforcement history) as well as Pavlovian CSs that have been associated with approach or avoidance/withdrawal (i.e., Pavlovian CSs bias action selection; Berridge et al., 2009).

Reinforcement history refers to how frequently and recently an action has been associated with a desirable or undesirable outcome. Greater frequency and recency results in a stronger association between the action and the outcome and a greater likelihood that the action will be carried out given the opportunity for reinforcement (Averbeck & Costa, 2017). However, reinforcement history also includes the context in which actions are performed. Pavlovian CSs can increase or decrease the likelihood that an action will be carried out if they have been associated with the Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.
outcome of that actionanother example of PIT (Corbit & Balleine, 2011;Ostlund & Balleine, 2008).

In MDD, negative memory biases are proposed to influence the recall of reinforcement history, including the frequency and recency of particular outcomes where negative outcomes are recalled as having occurred more frequently (Korn, Sharot, Walter, Heekeren, & Dolan, 2014).

As reported above in our review of instrumental conditioning studies, misleading negative feedback has been found to be weighted more heavily than overall reinforcement history for determining choice for individuals with MDD (Murphy et al., 2003;Tavares et al., 2008). CSs are proposed to be detected more readily than appetitive Pavlovian CSs (Anderson, Leal, Hall, Yassa, & Yantis, 2014), biasing action towards avoidance/withdrawal responses as opposed to approach (Trew, 2011). However, it is possible that action selection will result in inaction, for example if no effective instrumental response can be recalled (Raes et al., 2005) or if a Pavlovian CS is sufficiently aversive (an example of aversive PIT; Dayan & Huys, 2008;Nord et al., 2018),
as could be the case in MDD.

div.head: Effort tolerance versus estimated effort cost
div.p: If an effective instrumental action suitable to the context (as indicated by Pavlovian CSs that predict a successful outcome) is recalled, the next phase of the MELD framework includes competition between effort tolerance and estimated effort cost. Here, an individual's willingness to expend effort towards a particular outcome is pitted against the perceived effort required for the selected action (Treadway et al., 2012). In MDD, willingness to expend effort is expected to be low, whereas estimated effort cost is expected to be exaggerated (Cléry-Melin et Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission. al., 2011;Hershenberg et al., 2016;Sherdell, Waugh, & Gotlib, 2012). However, if effort tolerance is greater than or equal to estimated effort cost, the action to obtain or avoid a pleasant or unpleasant outcome, respectively, will be carried out. An individual with MDD exploring options in a food court would be expected to estimate that patiently waiting for food will require an abundant amount of effort and their willingness to wait patiently may be low. If their willingness to wait patiently is less than the effort (or energy) required to do so, they are unlikely to wait in line. Alternately, if an individual with MDD does not estimate that waiting in a line will require much effort, their willingness to wait may be sufficient for them to do so.

div.head: Outcome sensitivity and updating of priors
div.p: Once an action has been carried out, the success or failure of the action and an individual's subjective experience of the outcome as pleasant or unpleasant (referred to in the MELD framework as outcome sensitivity) will influence the updating of priors for the actionoutcome association (Berridge et al., 2009), as well as the cues and contexts that will now be associated with the outcome (again influenced by attentional bias). Updating of priors involves changes in (1) estimations of the pleasantness or unpleasantness of outcomes, (2) stimulusoutcome associations (i.e., Pavlovian conditioning), and (3) action-outcome associations (i.e., instrumental conditioning). Regarding the updating of priors for the pleasantness or unpleasantness of outcomes, stronger encoding and consolidation of positive and negative experiences will facilitate later recall of that experience for the purpose of estimating outcome value through cognitive desire/aversion, whereas weaker encoding and consolidation of positive and negative experiences will result in lower estimated outcome value. In MDD, increased punishment sensitivity and decreased reward sensitivity, as well as rumination of negative experiences that promotes consolidation of these memories, would be expected to promote recall Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

of negative experiences and their unpleasantness, and diminish the recall of positive experiences and their pleasantness (Hamilton & Gotlib, 2008;Levens & Gotlib, 2010;Watkins, Vache, Verney, & Mathews, 1996). The individual with MDD at the food court may have ruminated considerably in the past while waiting in line ups and not at all about the pleasant experience of enjoying the result of that action, i.e., delicious food. Therefore, this individual may easily recall how unpleasant it is to wait in a line and only vaguely recall the pleasantness of a meal (updating priors regarding how much each experience was 'liked' or 'disliked').

Outcome sensitivity would also be expected to bias the updating of priors for the recall of past actions and their outcomes, where associations between actions and consequent failure may be more likely to be strongly encoded and consolidated in MDD, leading to failed instrumental actions being recalled as occurring more frequently in general and more easily when the failed instrumental action occurred recently (affecting estimations of reinforcement history).

Individuals with MDD have been shown to have greater sensitivity to negative feedback (Ruchsow et al., 2006), which is consistent with findings from the instrumental conditioning studies reviewed above that individuals with MDD are more likely to guide their actions based on recent negative feedback as opposed to the overall reinforcement history (Murphy et al., 2003;Tavares et al., 2008).

Lastly, outcome sensitivity would influence the updating of priors for Pavlovian CSs, including conditioned associations between environmental stimuli and (1) their outcomes alone (affecting future motivational salience of these stimuli) and (2) stimuli and a representation of the action alone or a representation of both the action and its outcome (affecting future action selection; Dayan & Berridge, 2014), which in MDD would likely entail enhanced encoding and consolidation of cues in the environment that predict failure and blunted encoding and Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

consolidation of cues when outcomes are positive (i.e., successful instrumental actions). For example, if an individual with MDD attempts to engage a colleague at work in casual conversation and is told by the colleague that it is not a good time, they may attend to the person's body language and facial expression and these cues may be associated with a failure to connect with co-workers, even if these cues do not predict failure to engage with co-workers in the future.

To summarize, the updating of priors in the MELD framework involves updating future estimations of how pleasant or unpleasant an outcome is, the estimated reinforcement history for that particular action, and the environmental cues and context that predict that outcome. Each of these updates are influenced by outcome sensitivity, where greater sensitivity to negative outcomes in MDD may facilitate the updating of priors for disliking negative outcomes, actions that produce negative outcomes, and Pavlovian CSs that predict negative outcomes.

Alternatively, in MDD, less sensitivity to positive outcomes would inhibit updating of priors for liking positive outcomes, actions that lead to positive outcomes, and Pavlovian CSs that predict those outcomes.

div.head: Representation of PIT in the MELD framework
div.p: In our framework, we propose two ways altered PIT may be a barrier to obtaining positive reinforcement for individuals with MDD. The first is exaggerated influence of aversive and blunted influence of appetitive Pavlovian CSs on motivational salience. Enhanced aversive salience would be expected to increase the value of undesirable instrumental outcomes and lower the value of desirable instrumental outcomes. We further propose that blunted appetitive salience would result in limited influence of appetitive Pavlovian CSs on the value of both desirable and undesirable outcomes. The second way PIT is proposed to operate in MDD according to our Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.
framework is the influence of Pavlovian CSs on action selection (Berridge et al., 2009).

Specifically, attentional biases towards aversive Pavlovian CSs are proposed to bias the recall of ineffective as opposed to effective instrumental actions, as well as strong associations between aversive Pavlovian CSs and ineffective instrumental actions. Therefore, consistent with current conceptualizations of PIT (Balleine & Ostlund, 2007;Dorfman & Gershman, 2019), we propose that individuals with MDD are disadvantaged in terms of the general motivating properties of Pavlovian CSs on instrumental actions and their influence on action selection.

div.head: Comparing frameworks
div.p: The ACDM framework, which characterizes unique alterations in decision-making in anxiety and depression, was influential in the formulation of the MELD framework (Bishop & Gagne, 2018). Although our framework is applied only to MDD here, many aspects of our framework overlap with those included in the ACDM framework applied to depression. The primary psychological components of the ACDM framework, including the value of instrumental outcomes, the probability that an outcome will be obtained following various actions, and the estimation of effort required for particular actions, are broadly reflected in the MELD (instrumental outcome value, action selection, and effort tolerance versus estimated effort cost, respectively). Another important component of the ACDM framework applied to depressed mood is the suggestion that depressed individuals may have a reduced ability to recall actions that were associated with a desirable outcome, a feature that is also included in our framework.

What distinguishes the two frameworks is our incorporation of additional cognitive processes that may contribute to instrumental actions in MDD, most notably the influences of Pavlovian CSs on instrumental behaviour. Our framework also complements estimated effort cost with the concept of effort tolerance, reflecting the amount of effort an individual is willing to produce to Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

obtain the desired outcome. Here we separate the estimation of effort required from willingness to expend effort because both may affect whether an individual (successfully or unsuccessfully) exerts effort towards a desired outcome (Chong et al., 2016;Chong et al., 2015;Cléry-Melin et al., 2011). Thus, while these two frameworks are complementary, the MELD framework aims to provide broader account of emotional learning in MDD.

div.head: Future directions
div.p: The proposed framework, developed to aid in the characterization of emotional learning in MDD, offers a simplified account of how Pavlovian cues may influence instrumental behaviour. It does not address how the acquisition and extinction of Pavlovian associations may interact with instrumental behaviours in MDD. Due to the inconsistent findings in past studies examining aversive Pavlovian conditioning in MDD and paucity of studies investigating appetitive Pavlovian conditioning in MDD, further investigation is needed to address this gap.

Furthermore, while an abundance of research has investigated incentive salience and its clinical importance for problems like addiction (Berridge & Robinson, 2016), research and theory regarding aversive or fear salience is lacking despite its probable relevance to mental health conditions like MDD. Aversive Pavlovian influence over instrumental conditioning is proposed in our framework to play a critical role in maladaptive instrumental behaviours in MDD. A promising future direction for research on motivational salience and its clinical application would be the conceptualization and investigation of aversive salience and the role it may play in MDD. PIT is a paradigm that may be well-suited to such research, especially when primary aversive stimuli and socially relevant aversive stimuli are used as the US for Pavlovian training phases of PIT paradigms.
Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.

A notable omission from this article is the potential role of PIT in the propensity for, and onset of, MDD. Although research to date has not investigated this topic, we speculate that attentional and memory biases would facilitate exaggerated aversive Pavlovian control and blunted appetitive Pavlovian control over behaviours for individuals susceptible to depression.
As a consequence, individuals who are susceptible to depression would be expected to experience fewer positively reinforcing experiences overall, leading to bouts of depression.
Longitudinal studies examining how performance on PIT tasks relates to depression risk and the onset of MDD are needed to explore these hypotheses.

div.head: Conclusion
div.p: Emotional learning is considered to be an evolutionarily adaptive psychological process required for reflexively responding to anticipated significant events and performing actions that can promote desirable experiences and prevent or escape undesirable ones. Individual differences in emotional learning, including Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning and interactions between the two, can inform the emotional processes that contribute to and maintain MDD as well as potential treatments. Since, in real-world contexts, Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning are always under mutual influence, examining PIT in the context of depression is important for acquiring a more complete picture of the pattern of cognitive processes that contribute to and maintain depressive symptomology. To date, research on these topics is relatively limited considering the central role that behavioural theories of depression (which rely heavily on emotional learning principles) have played in understanding and treating MDD.

Further investigating MDD using emotional learning paradigms is essential for advancing our understanding of MDD from a behavioural perspective. Furthermore, informing future work with Draft version 1, 21/10/20. This paper has not been peer reviewed. Please do not copy or cite without author's permission.
a theoretical framework such as the one proposed here will aid in developing and refining a 1133 comprehensive characterization of emotional learning in MDD.

figure.figDesc: depressed individuals with MDD, aspects of the environment that have previously been associated with negative outcomes may suppress actions intended to bring about desirable outcomes and prevent undesirable ones. Furthermore, the MELD framework suggests that, for individuals who are depressed, actions intended to bring about desirable consequences are not invigorated by aspects of the environment that have previously signaled a concurrent or subsequent positive outcome (where nondepressed individuals would experience invigoration of such actions). The assumptions of the MELD framework are informed by emotional learning studies in currently depressed individuals who have been diagnosed with MDD. Before reviewing this research, however, we will provide a brief overview of behavioural theories of depression focused on the role of positive and negative reinforcement (as opposed to cognitive theories that emphasize the roles of negative thoughts and beliefs in depression) that set the stage for recent research investigating emotional learning in MDD.

s) of that behaviour (i.e., reinforcement or punishment; Dickinson, 2015). Reinforcement entails the presentation of a rewarding outcome (positive reinforcement) or the removal of an aversive outcome (negative reinforcement) as a consequence of behaviour, in turn making the behaviour more likely in the future. Punishment involves the presentation of an aversive consequence (positive punishment) or the removal of a rewarding consequence (negative punishment) as a result of behaviour. Subsequently, an organism becomes less likely to engage in that behaviour. In animal studies, prototypical examples of instrumental conditioning paradigms include scenarios in which animals learn to

(c) Participants then perform a PIT task test phase during which they are asked to select one of the two dots (the trained instrumental behaviour) in the presence of the Pavlovian cues (CS and CS-). The MELD framework integrates Pavlovian and instrumental conditioning and their interaction (i.e., Pavlovian-instrumental transfer or PIT) as well as relevant psychological processes for demonstrating how dysfunctional emotional learning dynamics may perpetuate a lack of positive reinforcement and/or preponderance of punishment and in turn depressive symptoms in MDD.
